body:
I found it stuck at `self.session.commit()` in `UDFRunner._apply`.

https://github.com/HazyResearch/fonduer/blob/01e0d9319b523aff7aa7f5c583a9f330b0705ecc/src/fonduer/utils/udf.py#L168

I think this is a regression from 807a4b8a5960ef8cd11df892f98bee60ecf9a804 (#490).
By this commit, all the changes during `parser.apply` are held in memory until they are flushed out to the database, which could easily overflow the RAM size when many documents are processed.

> I think the idea of processing the rows in chunks is to limit the
memory usage of the Python process. Until you call session.flush(),
all your modifications are held in memory. For small numbers of rows
this isn't a problem, but for huge numbers, it might be.

https://groups.google.com/g/sqlalchemy/c/hK4vIziMWOQ/m/98O5d2dqCgAJ

issue.title: Commit Document and related objects every doc iteration

repository.name: fonduer
repository.description: A knowledge base construction engine for richly formatted data

issue.body:
## Description of the problems or issues

**Is your pull request related to a problem? Please describe.**

See #494.

**Does your pull request fix any issue.**

Fix #494.

## Description of the proposed changes
A clear and concise description of what you propose.

## Test plan
A clear and concise description of how you test the new changes.

## Checklist

* [ ] I have updated the documentation accordingly.
* [ ] I have added tests to cover my changes.
* [ ] All new and existing tests passed.

body:
> By this commit, all the changes during `parser.apply` are held in memory until they are flushed out to the database, which could easily overflow the RAM size when many documents are processed.

Turns out this is not true.
Fonduer creates a `Session` by `sqlalchemy.orm.sessionmaker`, which uses `autoflush=True` by default.
https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/orm/session_api.html#session-and-sessionmaker

The changes are flushed out to the database. It's just they are not committed until all the docs are parsed.
Close for now as it turns out not to be easily reproducible.

Hi, I'm seeing this bug in the max_storage_temp_tutorial.
![Screen Shot 2021-01-25 at 3 29 39 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20375994/105778943-3a812100-5f22-11eb-9a8e-3d56579919c6.png)
It hangs here forever when I use the default 100 doc max. If I lower the max (e.g. 10), no issues.

I'm still seeing this issue. It looks like all processes' data are held in memory, then written to the DB using a single process. I'm debugging via `top`, where I see 
1. memory usage is split across parallel processes
2. next, all memory stacks up in a single process
3. lastly, my machine kills the process due to OOM error

I can workaround this via a for loop wrapper but this doesn't seem like the optimal way to use `.apply`. 

It seems @HiromuHota may have moved on to other projects; @SenWu, do you have time to look at this issue?

Your description sounds correct to me, and this is definitely a real bottleneck several have run into. We would love to try and resolve this, but I suspect it wouldn't be a quick fix. 

I'm going to reopen this issue.

issue.title: Resolve memory leaks caused by adding and commiting to postgres (related to #494)

repository.name: fonduer
repository.description: A knowledge base construction engine for richly formatted data

issue.body:
## Description of the problems or issues

**Is your pull request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Memory leaks happen when Fonduer adds and commits data to postgres after parsing many documents.
This causes `OOM killer` of Ubuntu and hangup Fonduer process. Please refer to #494.

**Does your pull request fix any issue.**
One of the memory leak problems is because sqlalchemy keeps all data, which are parsed from documents, on memory untill `commit` from `add`.

## Description of the proposed changes
Add `commit` to immediately after `add` to free memory (L136 of `src/fonduer/parser/parser.py`).
I’m definitely sure that no side effect happens because no processes exist with the data on the memory after `add` and `commit`.
By the way, there are two cases doing `commit` after multiple `add`; one is preparing a rollback of inserting data to postgres, and the other is accelerating insert processes for many small data. In contrast, document data in Fonduer are a few large data.

## Test plan
Run an existing tests (No additional tests).

## Checklist

* [x] I have updated the documentation accordingly.
* [x] I have added tests to cover my changes.
* [x] All new and existing tests passed.
* [x] I have updated the CHANGELOG.rst accordingly.

body:
I proposed a pull request related to this issue (#494) by #541.
OOM error seems to happen in the case that sqlalchemy keeps large document data on memory untill `commit` from `add`.
The proposal (#541) is doing `commit` immediately after `add` to free memory.
https://github.com/HazyResearch/fonduer/blob/5ab8e9c7bad34ad86800b7b077aa8342f590ec27/src/fonduer/parser/parser.py#L135

In addition, I got test results; python memory usage (max about 3GB -> 500MB) and processing time (339 sec -> 268 sec).
This test is parsing all html files from [tests/download_data.sh](https://github.com/HazyResearch/fonduer/blob/5ab8e9c7bad34ad86800b7b077aa8342f590ec27/tests/download_data.sh) and saving them to postgres.
Thanks for your work on this. This will be a major reliability improvement for my use case and will eliminate several workarounds.

issue.title: Resolve memory leaks caused by add and commit to postgres (related to #494, redo #541)

repository.name: fonduer
repository.description: A knowledge base construction engine for richly formatted data

issue.body:
## Description of the problems or issues

**Is your pull request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Memory leaks happen when Fonduer adds and commits data to postgres after parsing many documents.
This causes OOM killer of Ubuntu and hangup Fonduer process. Please refer to #494.
(This PR is redo of #541)

**Does your pull request fix any issue.**
One of the memory leak problems is because sqlalchemy keeps all data, which are parsed from documents, on memory untill `commit` from `add`.

## Description of the proposed changes
Add `commit` immediately after `add` to free memory.
https://github.com/HazyResearch/fonduer/blob/b0154c36b4feeda2e81ad7dd9af7062762dad3bf/src/fonduer/parser/parser.py#L135
I’m definitely sure that no side effect happens because no processes exist with the data on the memory after `add` and `commit`.
By the way, there are two cases doing `commit` after multiple `add`; one is preparing a rollback of inserting data to postgres, and the other is accelerating insert processes for many small data. In contrast, document data in Fonduer are a few large data.

## Test plan
Run an existing tests (No additional tests).

## Checklist

* [x] I have updated the documentation accordingly.
* [x] I have added tests to cover my changes.
* [x] All new and existing tests passed.
* [x] I have updated the CHANGELOG.rst accordingly.

body: I renew PR #544 from #541 because #541 fails rebase by my wrong merge order.
The proposed PR has been merged. @robbieculkin, if you happen to have time to test the current `master` branch to verify that this is working for you, that would be great.
